stem: A client is receiving a unit of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) that has been infusing for 3.5 hours. The client suddenly develops a temperature of 105.4°F (40.8°C) and shaking chills (rigors). Based on the documentation in the provided tabs, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Client experiencing extreme hyperpyrexia and shock during blood transfusion. Onset of symptoms was sudden.
Background: Rule-out sepsis due to possible bacterial contamination. Blood unit was hung late in the shift. No prior transfusion reactions.
Assessment: At 16:30, client is shivering violently with a core temperature of 105.4°F (40.8°C). Blood pressure has dropped from a baseline of 120/80 mmHg to 86/42 mmHg. Heart rate is 142 bpm and respiratory rate is 32 breaths/min. Oxygen saturation is 90% on room air.
Recommendation: Immediately stop the transfusion. Send the remaining blood and administration set to the laboratory for stat Gram stain and culture. Anticipate orders for IV fluids and vasopressors.

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: Pending: Gram stain and blood culture. Complete blood count (CBC) with differential. Comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP). Coagulation studies (PT/INR, PTT). Lactate level.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 86/42 mmHg, HR 142 bpm, RR 32 breaths/min, T 105.4°F (40.8°C), SpO2 90%.

tabs.title: Radiology
tabs.content: No radiology orders at this time.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Current medications: 0.9% Sodium Chloride IV at 100 mL/hr. PRBCs 1 unit infusing (started at 13:00).

actionOptions.text: Stop the transfusion immediately and disconnect the tubing from the IV hub.
Send the remaining blood bag and administration set to the laboratory/blood bank for culture.
Flush the IV line with 0.9% sodium chloride solution.
Apply warming blankets to alleviate the shivering/rigors.

parameterOptions.text: Blood pressure, mean arterial pressure (MAP), and core temperature.
Urine output and clarity (monitor for acute kidney injury).
Neurological status, including assessment for Babinski reflex.

rationale.correct: The client is exhibiting signs and symptoms consistent with a Septic Transfusion Reaction (c2). Bacterial contamination in the blood bag, often by Gram-negative bacteria, can lead to rapid-onset septic shock and a high fever (105°F/40.8°C or higher). The key indicators are the extreme fever spike, rigors, and the absence of hemoglobinuria (which would suggest a hemolytic reaction). The priority nursing actions are to immediately stop the transfusion (a1) to prevent further exposure to the contaminated blood and send the blood bag and administration set to the laboratory/blood bank for culture (a2) to identify the causative pathogen. Monitoring should focus on the resulting septic shock (p1), including blood pressure, MAP, and core temperature, as well as renal function (p2) by monitoring urine output and clarity to detect potential acute kidney injury.
clinicalPearls: Blood products should be infused within 4 hours of removal from controlled refrigeration. Prolonged hang time increases the risk of bacterial proliferation.
Symptoms of a septic transfusion reaction can manifest immediately or up to several hours after the transfusion is completed.
A fever in a septic transfusion reaction is typically a significant increase (2°F/1.1°C or more) above the client's baseline temperature and may be accompanied by vomiting and/or diarrhea.

questionTrap.trap: Assuming that all fever during a blood transfusion indicates a hemolytic reaction.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Carefully assess the client's signs and symptoms. Hemolytic reactions often present with flank pain and dark urine (hemoglobinuria). Septic reactions are characterized by a very high fever (105°F/40.8°C or higher), rigors (shaking chills), and a rapid drop in blood pressure.

mnemonic.title: Septic Shakes
mnemonic.expansion: S-Spiking Temperature (105°F/40.8°C or higher). H-Hypotension. A-Always culture the blood bag and administration set. K-Keep away from the patient (Stop the transfusion). E-Extreme chills (Rigors). S-Send the blood back to the lab.
